notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Fünf' има умлаут ü (произнася се като между 'ю' и 'и'). Внимание при писане на 15: 'fünfzehn'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Пет' ≈ 'fünf'. Zahlwort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Numbers in Bulgarian follow Slavic pattern. Gender agreement with counted nouns

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Sechs' завършва на -chs и се произнася като 'зекс'. В множествени съставки: 'sechzehn', 'sechzig'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Шест' ≈ 'sechs'. Zahlwort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Numbers in Bulgarian follow Slavic pattern. Gender agreement with counted nouns

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Sieben' губи 'e' в 'siebzehn' (17) и 'siebzig' (70). Произношението е 'зибън'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Седем' ≈ 'sieben'. Zahlwort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Numbers in Bulgarian follow Slavic pattern. Gender agreement with counted nouns

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Acht' се произнася с мек 'х' [ахт]. В съставни числа 'achtzehn', 'achtzig', 'achtundzwanzig'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Осем' ≈ 'acht'. Zahlwort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Numbers in Bulgarian follow Slavic pattern. Gender agreement with counted nouns

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Neun' се произнася 'нойн'. Запомнете формите 'neunzehn' и 'neunzig'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Девет' ≈ 'neun'. Zahlwort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Numbers in Bulgarian follow Slavic pattern. Gender agreement with counted nouns

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Zehn' се произнася [tseːn] и образува сложни числа като 'zehn Uhr' (десет часа).
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Десет' ≈ 'zehn'. Zahlwort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Numbers in Bulgarian follow Slavic pattern. Gender agreement with counted nouns

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Elf' се произнася кратко [ɛlf] и често обозначава възраст: 'Er ist elf Jahre alt'. Няма умлаут и не се променя в сложни числа като 'elf Uhr'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Единадесет' entsteht aus 'един' + 'надесет'. Betonung: единаде́сет. Merken: zusätzliche Silbe 'на'.
notes.linguisticForBulgarians: Stress on единаде́сет. German 'elf' is monosyllabic with [ɛlf].
notes.linguisticForGermans: Stress on единаде́сет. German 'elf' is monosyllabic with [ɛlf].

etymology: From 'един' (one) + 'над десет' (over ten). Literally 'one over ten'.
culturalNotes: Bulgarian teens (11-19) add 'надесет'. German writes 11-19 as one word without spaces.

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Zwölf' е с умлаут ö и произношение [tsvœlf]. В часовник често се казва 'zwölf Uhr'. В съставни числа стои отпред: 'zwölfmal'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Дванадесет' = 'zwölf'. Beachten Sie den Umlaut 'ö' in Deutsch und die Endung '-десет' im Bulgarischen.
notes.linguisticForBulgarians: Stress on дванаде́сет. German 'zwölf' carries Umlaut (ö) and [tsvœlf].
notes.linguisticForGermans: Stress on дванаде́сет. German 'zwölf' carries Umlaut (ö) and [tsvœlf].

etymology: From 'две' (two) + 'над десет' (over ten). Literally 'two over ten'.
culturalNotes: Used in both everyday counting and telling the time (e.g., noon).

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Dreizehn' комбинира 'drei' + 'zehn' и се произнася [ˈdʁaɪ̯tseːn]. Използва се и като прилагателно: 'dreizehn Schüler'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Тринадесет' folgt dem Muster Grundzahl + 'надесет'. Betonung auf '-де́-'.
notes.linguisticForBulgarians: Stress on тринаде́сет. German 'dreizehn' keeps 'drei' stem and uses [ˈdʁaɪ̯tseːn].
notes.linguisticForGermans: Stress on тринаде́сет. German 'dreizehn' keeps 'drei' stem and uses [ˈdʁaɪ̯tseːn].

etymology: From 'три' (three) + 'над десет'. Bulgarian pattern parallels German 'drei' + 'zehn'.
culturalNotes: Both cultures consider 13 sometimes unlucky, but it is common in daily use.

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Zwanzig' се пише с 'z' и се произнася [ˈtsvanʦɪç]. В съставни числа (21) немският ред е 'einundzwanzig'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: Bulgarisch fügt 'десет' an, Deutsch nutzt die Endung '-zig'.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Stress on два́десет. German 'zwanzig' pronounced [ˈtsvanʦɪç].

etymology: From 'два' (two) + 'десет'. German 'zwanzig' derives from 'zwei' + '-zig'.
culturalNotes: Round numbers like 20 are used in pricing and ages (20 години).

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Viele' се използва с броими съществителни: 'viele Bücher'. За неброими използвайте 'viel'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Много' ≈ 'viele'. Bulgarisches Wort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Common Bulgarian word at A2 level. Useful for everyday communication

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Wenig' означава 'малко'; за множествено може да чуете 'wenige Leute'. Противоположно на 'viel/viele'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Малко' ≈ 'wenig'. Bulgarisches Wort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Common Bulgarian word at A2 level. Useful for everyday communication

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Alle' изисква множествено число: 'alle Freunde'. В комбинация с определителен член става 'alle die'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Всички' ≈ 'alle'. Bulgarisches Wort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Common Bulgarian word at A2 level. Useful for everyday communication

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Einige' обозначава неопределен малък брой: 'einige Tage' (няколко дни).
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Няколко' ≈ 'einige'. Bulgarisches Wort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Common Bulgarian word at A2 level. Useful for everyday communication

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Keiner' е отрицателен заменящ за хора: 'Keiner kommt.' За съществителни използвайте 'kein' + род ('kein Auto').
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Никой' ≈ 'keiner'. Bulgarisches Wort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Common Bulgarian word at A2 level. Useful for everyday communication

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Samstag' е стандартното название; на юг често се използва 'Sonnabend'. Използвайте 'am Samstag'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Събота' ≈ 'Samstag'. Bulgarisches Wort. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Common Bulgarian word at A2 level. Useful for everyday communication

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Die Stunde' означава 60 минути. Фраза: 'zwei Stunden warten'. Не се бърка с 'die Uhr' (часовник).
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Час' ≈ 'Stunde'. Zeitbegriff. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Time concept in Bulgarian. Note that времеmeans both 'time' and 'weather'

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Die Minute' е женски род. Във време на часовник: 'Es ist fünf Minuten nach neun.' Съкратено 'Min.'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Минута' ≈ 'Minute'. Zeitbegriff. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Time concept in Bulgarian. Note that времеmeans both 'time' and 'weather'

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Der Morgen' обозначава периода до обяд. Фраза: 'am Morgen', а при пожелание 'Guten Morgen!'.
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Сутрин' ≈ 'Morgen'. Zeitbegriff. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Time concept in Bulgarian. Note that времеmeans both 'time' and 'weather'

notes.forBulgarianSpeakers: 'Der Mittag' е обедът (~12 ч.). Изрази: 'am Mittag', 'Mittagessen' (обяд).
notes.forGermanSpeakers: Für Deutschsprachige: 'Обед' ≈ 'Mittag'. Zeitbegriff. Häufig verwendet.
notes.linguisticForGermans: Bulgarian word at word level. Pay attention to stress and pronunciation

etymology: Slavic origin word. Related to other South Slavic languages
culturalNotes: Time concept in Bulgarian. Note that времеmeans both 'time' and 'weather'
